name: 生物地理與自然保育研討
goals: To understand how and what role that biogeography plays in real-world nature conservation.
To induct cutting-edge concepts on biodiversity conservation, and the mindfulness of natural environment.
Participants may acquire basic skills on protect area design and management.
syllabus:
**Description**

Students who had taken biogeography and/or conservation biology courses at undergraduate level are familiar with the essences of classic theories or golden cases, but not necessarily track the context precisely. This course is to encourage students to examine the original research papers, and to seek in-depth knowledge in biogeography. Through a weekly journal club-style discussion led by the instructor, guest speakers, and peers, the course is designed not only to enhance the students’ specialised knowledge in biogeography, but also to help the students accustom themselves reading and analysing research papers critically - even with the classic ones.

As how it was in Fall 2020, the SBNC course for 2022 will also be held in an informal, seminar-like forum format. However, in this year we will spend most of the time reading and discussing a number of classic texts selected from 'Foundations of Biogeography: Classic Papers with Commentaries,' which was edited by the renowned biogeographer Mark Lomolino and his colleagues.

Prior knowledge in biogeography, ecology, and/or evolutionary biology is highly recommended but not required for taking this course.

This is an EMI course. All participants are anticipated to actively express their thoughts with spoken and written English.

**Course Structure**

The course will be taught in forum-style, being held once a week for 16 weeks. Each course session will usually consist of a brief introduction by the host-of-the-day, followed by an extensive group discussion session with no obvious break in between. All students should attend all sessions and engage attentively in the discussion.

**Prerequisite** None

**Language**         English

**Class Size**         Ideal class size would be <20 postgraduate students

**Credit System**

No formal exams for the course. Credits will be evaluated through the regularity of attendance, levels of engagement in the discussion, and the quality of final paper.

*   weekly assignment & feedback (25%)
*   attendance & engagement in discussion (35%)
*   final paper (40%)

Leave and make-up: No late assignment turn in. No skip is allowed throughout the course. For unforeseeable incidents including traffic disruption or serious personal issues, the student should consult with the instructor within one week after the incident and provide relevant evidences or creditable proofs.
